Award.AwardTitle: Problems on the geometric function theory in several complex variables and complex geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This mathematics research project by Yuan Yuan concerns a number of problems in several complex variables and complex differential geometry, consisting of the rigidity and classification of holomorphic structures, canonical metrics in Kahler geometry, and complex Monge-Ampere equations. These are fundamental problems closely related to many other fields in mathematics and physics, such as, algebraic geometry, mathematical physics, number theory, partial differential equations. In particular, Yuan will study the uniqueness of complex structure on Hermitian symmetric spaces and mapping rigidity between bounded symmetric domains; and the deep relation between the (finite and infinite time) limit behavior of the (parabolic) complex Monge-Ampere equations and canonical Kahler metrics as well as the formation of singularities on Kahler manifolds.

The mathematics field of complex analysis took center stage starting with the nineteenth century, when its applications became crucial to other sciences and engineering, including electronic engineering and mechanic engineering. Over the years, this trend has continued and in fact has been taken to the next level: the geometric spaces studied in this mathematics research project by Yuan Yuan can serve as the most basic models in cosmology and general relativity. Clarifying the geometric structure of these models is extremely important in understanding the physical laws that relate to them and can help further our understanding of the shape of the universe. In addition to this work, Yuan will continue to participate in, and organize seminars and workshops for undergraduate and graduate students and young researchers. Yuan will also mentor undergraduate and graduate students, and in this way the project will effectively integrate research and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant supported Yuan's research in several complex variables and complex geometry, focusing on a number of problems closely related to many other fields in mathematics and physics, such as, algebraic geometry, mathematical physics, number theory, partial differential equations. The research aims to clarify the geometric structures which may be served as the basic models of moduli spaces in algebraic geometry as well as models in cosmology and general relativity and it also aims to develop the fundamental analytic tools for geometric nonlinear partial differential equations which are indispensable to understand the canonical metrics.
During the period of the grant, Yuan has been working on the proposed projects on holomorphic maps preserving metric structures, on the rigidity of CR maps, on geometric flows towards canonical K\"ahler metrics. Among research outcomes, Yuan classified the germs of holomorphic isometries between compact Hermitian symmetric spaces in a joint work with Huang. The techniques in proving the algebraicity of the germs of the maps turned out to be quite useful in related problems. Among others, for instance, Huang and Yuan answered a question of Di Scala on the holomorphically isometrically embedded common submanifold for bounded symmetric domains and complex Euclidean spaces, by applying the above-mentioned techniques. In the classification result for holomorphic isometries from the complex unit ball to type IV classical domains of Xiao and Yuan, the idea can be further generalized to study the proper holomorphic maps from the complex unit balls to bounded symmetric domains, a much broader class of holomorphic maps that have received intensive attentions for more than thirty years. We proved the classification for proper holomorphic maps from the complex unit balls to type IV classical domains in small codimensions, and hope to make further progresses when the codimension is large or the boundary regularity is weaker, in connection to the recent development in CR geometry and reflection principles.
The grant supported Yuan to organize two AMS special sessions in 2014 at Baltimore, MD and in 2016 at Salt Lake City, Utah, as well as two international conferences in 2016 in Jilin, China and Beijing, China. The grant funded over thirty speakers in the seminars and colloquiums at Yuan's home institute, Syracuse University and supported various research visitors as well, among whom, a large part are junior researchers. M. Xiao visited Syracuse University several times when he was a graduate student at Rutgers and a postdoc at UIUC and his visitation resulted in three joint papers. J. Zhu visited Syracuse University for one month when he was a graduate student in Johns Hopkins University and there is one publication out of his visitation.


Last Modified: 06/21/2017
Modified by: Yuan Yuan
